title: World's most asked questions: how can I get rid of the hiccups?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: An involuntary spasm of the diaphragm

options.label: C
options.text: Drinking a tall glass of water

multiple-choice.question: Which muscle under the lungs is responsible for controlling breathing and is often involved in hiccups?
What is the main function of the vagus nerve in relation to hiccups?

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the diaphragm contractions and breathing patterns

multiple-choice.question: What is a common approach to getting rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream?
According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of people preferred holding their breath to relieve hiccups?
What is the role of the vocal folds in producing the "hic" sound during a hiccup?

options.label: C
options.text: To clamp shut when the diaphragm contracts suddenly

multiple-choice.question: Why do hiccups sometimes stop on their own, but other times require intervention?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the diaphragm's natural contractions

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the vagus nerve's constant stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Because the body needs to reset its nervous system

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the body's natural reflexes to regulate breathing

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of gulping down dry granules of sugar on the vagus nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes the vagus nerve to focus on the diaphragm

options.label: B
options.text: It causes the vagus nerve to focus on the throat

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the vagus nerve

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the vagus nerve to contract

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the body's natural breathing rhythms?

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream

multiple-choice.question: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the second most popular method for relieving hiccups among those who filled out the survey?
What is the relationship between the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and the body's breathing rhythms?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no effect on breathing rhythms

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the level of breathing

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the level of breathing

options.label: D
options.text: It regulates the level of breathing

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of people, according to the SciShow Survey, said that drinking water was their preferred method for relieving hiccups?
What is the role of the diaphragm in breathing and hiccups?

options.label: C
options.text: To contract suddenly and cause hiccups

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to swallow a teaspoon of sugar?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is dry and hard to swallow

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the vagus nerve and the diaphragm?

options.label: A
options.text: The vagus nerve controls the diaphragm

options.label: B
options.text: The vagus nerve is controlled by the diaphragm

options.label: C
options.text: The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm's contractions

options.label: D
options.text: The vagus nerve has no effect on the diaphragm

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of drinking a glass of water on the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases the level of carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the level of carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the level of carbon dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: It regulates the level of carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of people said that they had tried holding their breath to relieve hiccups?
What is the relationship between the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and the body's natural breathing rhythms?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no effect on breathing rhythms

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases the level of breathing

options.label: C
options.text: It increases the level of breathing

options.label: D
options.text: It regulates the level of breathing

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the vocal folds in producing the "hic" sound during a hiccup?

options.label: C
options.text: To clamp shut when the diaphragm contracts suddenly

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often try to hold their breath to relieve hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a natural reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a common remedy

options.label: C
options.text: Because it increases the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has no effect on the diaphragm

title: Architecture adventure: Crash Course Kids

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that the speaker wants to solve in the video?

options.label: A
options.text: They need a place to relax and have some space to themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: They want to design a robot to rescue their phone from a storm drain.

options.label: C
options.text: They want to build a treehouse for their family.

options.label: D
options.text: They are designing a new product to sell online.

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what is one way to block out sounds from outside when creating a secluded space in a room?

options.label: A
options.text: By hanging blankets from the ceiling.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a "Do Not Enter" sign.

multiple-choice.question: What is the engineering process that the speaker mentions in the video?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves designing buildings and structures, considering variables and potential failure points, and testing and refining the design.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves testing and trial-and-error methods.

options.label: C
options.text: It involves analyzing data and statistics.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves solving complex mathematical equations.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest using the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a secluded space?

options.label: A
options.text: By defining the problem, brainstorming solutions, testing and refining the design, and considering the variables and potential failure points.

options.label: B
options.text: By building a prototype and ignoring the need for testing and refinement.

options.label: C
options.text: By asking someone else to solve it for them.

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the problem and doing something else.

multiple-choice.question: What are some variables that the speaker mentions as being important to consider when designing the treehouse?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of the treehouse and the weight of the treehouse, the number and size of the blankets used for soundproofing, and the amount of noise made inside the treehouse.

options.label: B
options.text: The color of the treehouse and the type of wood used.

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the treehouse and the time of day it is used.

options.label: D
options.text: The height of the treehouse and the number of windows.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential failure point that the speaker mentions when considering the weight capacity of the treehouse?

options.label: A
options.text: The tree might not be able to support the weight of the treehouse.

options.label: B
options.text: The tree might be able to support the weight of the treehouse, but not the weight of the people inside it.

options.label: C
options.text: The tree might be able to support the weight of the people inside the treehouse, but not the weight of the treehouse itself.

options.label: D
options.text: The treehouse might not be able to support the weight of the people inside it, but the tree itself can support the weight of the treehouse.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest combining the ideas of adjusting a space they already have and creating a new space to solve the problem of needing a secluded space?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a combination of both ideas to create a unique solution, such as hanging blankets from the ceiling to block out sounds and creating a treehouse with a drop-down rope ladder.

options.label: B
options.text: By choosing one idea over the other and sticking with no compromise.

options.label: C
options.text: By ignoring one idea and only using the other.

options.label: D
options.text: By asking someone else to decide which idea to use.

multiple-choice.question: What is one benefit of using the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a secluded space?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for a quick and easy solution.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a thorough and well-thought-out solution that considers the variables and potential failure points.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a solution that can be implemented immediately.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker suggest testing and refining the design of the treehouse?

options.label: A
options.text: By building a prototype and conducting trials to isolate the variables and identify failure points, such as the weight capacity of the treehouse and the effectiveness of the soundproofing.

options.label: B
options.text: By ignoring the need for testing and refinement.

options.label: C
options.text: By asking someone else to test and refine the design.

options.label: D
options.text: By only testing the design once before building it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the video, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The video is about the importance of having a secluded space.

options.label: B
options.text: The video is about the engineering process and how it can be used to solve problems, such as designing a treehouse that meets the success criteria and navigates the variables.

options.label: C
options.text: The video is about the design of the treehouse and how it meets the success criteria.

options.label: D
options.text: The video is about the importance of collaboration and teamwork.

title: Gang of 3 | Sound of 3 consonants

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea presented in the transcript about consonants?

options.label: A
options.text: Consonants are used to create different words.

options.label: B
options.text: Consonants can be grouped into gangs of three to help with reading and spelling.

options.label: C
options.text: Consonants are the only sounds used in language.

options.label: D
options.text: Consonants are not important for language.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what can help you break down a word into smaller chunks?

options.label: C
options.text: A group of consonants called a gang

multiple-choice.question: How can knowing about consonant gangs help you with reading and spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes words harder to read and spell.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes words easier to read and spell by breaking them down into smaller chunks.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on reading and spelling.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following consonant groups is an example of a gang of three?
What is the author's attitude towards their gang of three?

options.label: A
options.text: They think they are the weakest gang.

options.label: B
options.text: They think they are the toughest gang and want others to watch out for them.

options.label: C
options.text: They are neutral about their gang.

options.label: D
options.text: They don't have an opinion about their gang.

multiple-choice.question: How can you apply the knowledge of consonant gangs to real-world reading and spelling tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: By ignoring the author does not explicitly state how to apply the knowledge of consonant gangs to real-world reading and spelling tasks, however, based on the context, the correct answer would be

options.label: B
options.text: By breaking down words into smaller chunks using consonant gangs to make them easier to read and spell.

options.label: C
options.text: By only using consonant gangs for spelling.

options.label: D
options.text: By only using consonant gangs for reading.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the consonant gang "thr" and the word "throw"?

options.label: B
options.text: They are two different consonant gangs.

options.label: C
options.text: "thr" is a part of the word "throw".

multiple-choice.question: How can you combine the ideas of consonant gangs and word breaking to create a new strategy for reading and spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: By ignoring consonant gangs and focusing on individual words.

options.label: B
options.text: By using consonant gangs to break down words into smaller chunks, making them easier to read and spell.

options.label: C
options.text: By only using consonant gangs for spelling.

options.label: D
options.text: By only using consonant gangs for reading.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's tone when they say "no we are so watch out for the gang of three"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are being polite and friendly.

options.label: B
options.text: They are being serious and warning.

options.label: C
options.text: They are being neutral and uninterested.

options.label: D
options.text: They are being sarcastic and joking.

multiple-choice.question: How can you evaluate the effectiveness of using consonant gangs for reading and spelling?

options.label: A
options.text: By only looking at individual words.

options.label: B
options.text: By breaking down words into smaller chunks using consonant gangs and comparing the results to not using them.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: By only using consonant gangs for spelling.

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the world's scariest viruses mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: Ebola, Hendra, SARS, Nipah, and Marburg

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the likely reason for the recent rise in outbreaks of diseases like Ebola and SARS?

options.label: A
options.text: The viruses are becoming more aggressive

options.label: B
options.text: Humans and animals are encroaching on bats' territory

options.label: C
options.text: The viruses are being transmitted through contaminated water

options.label: D
options.text: The viruses are becoming less deadly

multiple-choice.question: What is a common characteristic of bats that may contribute to the spread of viruses?

options.text: They are solitary animals and only roost alone

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are nocturnal and only active at night

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what may be the reason for bats' resilience to infection?

options.text: Their DNA is more resistant to damage

options.label: B
options.text: They have a strong immune system

options.label: C
options.text: Flight may be the reason bats are so resilient to infection

options.label: D
options.text: A and C (Flight and DNA damage repair kits)

options.label: C
options.text: They are finicky and require a perfectly controlled climate

options.label: A
options.text: They become more susceptible to viruses

options.label: B
options.text: They become more resistant to viruses

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of learning from bats' immune systems?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: We may be able to develop new antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: We may be able to develop new insecticides

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans are the primary carriers of diseases

options.label: B
options.text: Because humans are the primary victims of diseases

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans are the primary cause of diseases

options.label: D
options.text: Because humans are the primary solution to diseases

options.label: A
options.text: We may be able to control the spread of diseases carried by bats

options.label: B
options.text: We may be able to develop new treatments for bat-related diseases

options.label: C
options.text: We may be able to learn from bats' immune systems and develop new cancer treatments

options.label: D
options.text: We may be able to develop new insecticides

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between bats and the spread of viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Bats are the primary carriers of viruses

options.label: B
options.text: Bats are the primary victims of viruses

options.label: C
options.text: Bats are the primary cause of viruses

options.label: D
options.text: Bats may have helped viruses become virtually immune to humans

title: What is a coronavirus? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the virus that caused the SARS epidemic in 2003?

options.label: C
options.text: Through close contact with an infected person, such as touching or shaking hands

options.label: D
options.text: Through the air, without the need for close contact

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why coronaviruses tend to be more stable than other RNA viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a faster mutation rate

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are smaller in size

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a unique enzyme that checks for replication errors and corrects mistakes

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a slower mutation rate

options.label: C
options.text: Because the influenza virus is less stable

options.label: D
options.text: Because the influenza virus is less recognizable to our immune systems

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between coronaviruses and most other RNA viruses?

options.label: B
options.text: Coronaviruses have a faster mutation rate

options.label: C
options.text: Coronaviruses have a unique enzyme that checks for replication errors and corrects mistakes

multiple-choice.question: Why are coronaviruses more difficult to fight off than other viruses?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a slower mutation rate of mutation

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are less recognizable to our immune systems, making it harder for the immune system to mount an effective response

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a unique enzyme that checks for replication errors

options.label: C
options.text: It makes them more difficult to fight off

options.label: D
options.text: It makes our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines more effective, as they can more easily recognize and target the virus

title: Closed and open syllables | Learn to read

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule for determining whether a syllable is open or closed?

options.label: A
options.text: The syllable is open if it ends with a consonant and closed if it ends with a vowel.

options.label: B
options.text: The vowel says its letter name when the syllable is open, and makes a short sound when it's closed.

options.label: C
options.text: The syllable is open if it has a double vowel and closed if it has a single vowel.

options.label: D
options.text: The syllable is open if it has a consonant cluster and closed if it has a single consonant.

options.text: So we can spell words more accurately.

options.label: C
options.text: So we can pronounce words more correctly.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The vowel sound is affected by the type of syllable.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us to understand the meaning of words.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps us to recognize word patterns.

options.label: B
